summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding jury selection procedures in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The government requests clarification on when parties will receive prospective jurors' names and argues against providing identifying information weeks in advance, citing other high-profile cases as precedent.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the document (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom this letter is addressed regarding jury selection procedures.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter to the court.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell.
Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against Maxwell.

events.title: Court Order on Jury Selection Remarks
events.description: The court issued an order with draft preliminary remarks to be played before each jury questionnaire session.

events.title: Scheduled Oral Voir Dire
events.description: The date oral jury selection (voir dire) is scheduled to begin in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Start
events.description: The date the trial in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to commence.

keyFacts: The government is seeking clarification on when parties will receive names of prospective jurors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, requesting they not be provided until the day oral voir dire begins (November 16, 2021).

The government argues that having juror identifying information weeks in advance is unusual and unnecessary, citing the purpose of voir dire is to ascertain disqualifications, not to allow parties to mold the jury.
The government references other high-profile cases in the district (Skelos, Kaloyeros, Percoco, Parnas) as precedent for jury selection procedures.
The document reveals extended timing between jury questionnaire administration, oral voir dire, and trial start due to COVID-19 precautions.
